text: 750 ml bottle into tulip glass; 2015 vintage bottling, 9.9%. Pours fairly crystal clear dark ruby red/light brown color with a 1-2 finger fairly dense and fluffy light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of huge sweet/sour/tangy cherries, raisin, plum, raspberry, blackberry, currant, red grape, lemon, lime, green apple, almond, vanilla, bourbon, toasted oak, brown sugar, caramel, and bread; with light notes of leathery funk, red wine vinegar, pepper, and yeast/oak earthiness. Incredible aromas with amazing balance and complexity of fruity/acidic yeast, cherries, wine/bourbon barrels, and dark/bready malt notes; with big strength. Taste of huge sweet/sour/tangy cherries, raisin, plum, raspberry, blackberry, currant, red grape, lemon, lime, green apple, almond, vanilla, bourbon, toasted oak, brown sugar, caramel, and bread; with light notes of leathery funk, red wine vinegar, pepper, and yeast/oak earthiness. Light-moderate fruity/lactic tart/sourness; light yeast/oak spiciness and fruit tang on the finish. Lingering notes of sweet/sour cherries, raisin, plum, raspberry, blackberry, currant, red grape, lemon, lime, green apple, almond, vanilla, bourbon, toasted oak, brown sugar, caramel, bread, light funk/vinegar, and yeast/oak earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/acidic yeast, cherries, wine/bourbon barrels, and dark/bready malt flavors; with an awesome malt/tart/sourness balance, and minimal puckering flavors after the finish. Light-moderate dryness from tart/sourness and yeast/oak spiciness, increasing through the glass. Medium carbonation and medium-full body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/silky/acidic, and lightly tangy/tannic balanced mouthfeel that is amazing. Minimal warming alcohol for 9.9%. Overall this is an insane fruited Flanders red ale style! All around incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of fruity/acidic yeast, cherries, wine/bourbon barrels, and dark/bready malt flavors; very smooth and dangerously easy to drink with the balanced lactic/tannic/drying finish. Perfectly balanced complexity from all flavors. A highly amazing offering, and world class fruited sour ale. One of the best Ive ever had.
Thanks Danny! Super tart and boozy sour red. A beer drinkers beer - sour with high abv. Anyways, it was nicely balanced for extreme tastes. Great stuff!

Tart raspberry aroma with sudsy off white head. Puckeringly tart raspberry like woody aroma. 

Notes: 2015 vintage, on tap at he brewery, Portland visit May 17

Pours opaque chocolate brown with a serviceable buff head. Aroma offers a sharp note of tart fruit plus a little toasted malt. Flavor features tart, tart fruit - stone fruit and pomme - and just a hint of malt. Mouthfeel delivers firm body and peppy fizz. Black blood indeed.

Aromat intensywny, owocowy, nuty czerwonych, przejrzałych czereśni, nuty śliwek z niuansami wanilii w tle. 
W smaku wysoka kwaśność, czereśnie, śliwki, w tle niuanse karmelowe i czerwonego wina. Posmak wanilii i cierpkość drewna. Bardzo złożone.
750 ml bottle from Tavour. Nose is red wine, light vanilla, and bourbon. Clear rusty red with a medium lightly lacing beige head. Flavor is moderately tart with a hint of bourbon and vanilla.

Murky dark amber color with beige head. Aroma has balsamic vinegar, plums, tart fruits, some caramel malt in the background. Taste is sour up-front, acetic and astringent, some wood notes and the wine also comes through. Medium body and carbonation, quite dry and acidic. A great flanders style ale with complex flavors.
Bottle shared at a tasting. Dark brown with a thin tan head. Notes of dark cherries, apple vinegar, nice oak notes, light vanilla, more cherries. Very acidic, medium tart and quite complex.

Bottle. Wood, fresh hay, tart cherry, and caramel malt aroma. Brown with small head. Moderately sweet cherry, caramel and moderately bitter/astringent hay/wood flavor. Nice body and balance. Very nice.

No head, brown-red clear beer. Fruity nose, dark fruit, plums, alcohol. Speculoos , dark fruit flavours, but sour, acidic, as seemingly all Cascade products. Acidthinning and -burn. Certainly not the worst Cascade, not the best either.

Bottle shared @Pułapka, Gdańsk
Lacquer and red fruit, a bit of vinegar and vanilla. Taste is great, nicely sour and fruity, very nice and round vanilla on the finish
In aroma grape, bit of oak and alcohol, In taste, oak, grape, vinegar, and lether

Süß säuerlicher Geruch. Dezente Säure, leicht fruchtig, milde helle Holzigkeit. Geringe Bitterkeit, spritzig, Zitrus. Langer Nachhall, weich, die Säure weicht dabei von allen Aromen als erstes. 10/13/12/12/12/13

Aroma: vanilla, vinegar, wine, earthy, marzipan, oak
Taste: medium sour, light sweet, vanilla, marzipan, oak, earthy, wine, vinegar
Oily aftertaste

From 75cl bottle at Grand Cru, Rimini, Italy. Pours dark red with creamy limited foam. Aroma is somehow acetic. Body is medium-dense. Taste is sour, maybe more ascetic though not extreme, and with some sweetness. Long finish.

Rami Rami is drinking a Sang Noir by Cascade Brewing Company (USA) at BrewDog Warszawa

Zlozone, ciekawe, BBA czuc nie tylko wanilia, figi, ocet, wino, wisnie, drewno, fajnie przechodzi z kwasnosci w slodycz i spowrotem. Klasa
Butelka w brewdog. Beczka po bourbonie, czerwone wino, wisnia, moze sliwka. Cierpkie, umiarkowana kwaśnosc. Ściągające. Alkohol ladnie ułożony.

Wow! For that price I wanted extraordinary beer.. and I got one. Awesome complex cherry notes comes in different waves of enjoyment all the way staying crisp royal and dry.
Awesome BA impact gives dry oak, some other berry like notes, green leaves. Moderate sweetness with quite intense tartness, but awesome balance
Dark red. Very specific and strong taste. Nuances of cherry, oak. Different nuances in taste
Dark brown bit reddish with almost no head. Sour bit sweet berry aroma, touch of bourbon. Quite strong cherry sourness with notes of other berries and some touch of bourbon. Sour lasting aftertaste.

Poured from a 750 ml, 2011 Project bottle. 
Aroma is malt and cherry. Some caramel, toffee, toasted bread and hints of chocolate with moderate cherry notes as well as some raisin, fig and light berry notes. Hints of the oak and the alcohol. 
Pours brown with some auburn hues and a medium small, moderately thick, dark tan head that recedes quickly to the edges where it lingers for some time. Light lacing and small legs. 
Flavor is moderately acidic with a bit of a sharpness to it that lingers into the finish. Moderate malt notes with caramel, toffee, toasted bread and hints of chocolate and roast. Moderately strong tart cherry notes with some berry, raisin, fig and prune. Some light alcohol notes in the finish with hints of oak. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and low, but present alcohol warmth. 
Overall, about what I expect form a beer like this. A bit too acidic and sharp for my preferences. Lots of fruit and malt notes. Some light alcohol and oak notes.

Bottle
Aroma-sour fruits, wine, bourbon
Appearance-red, clear, tan foam, 
Taste-heavily sour, lightly bitter, light sweetness, 
Palate-full body, sticky, average carbonation, long finish, 
Overall-perfect

750ml bottle shared by ??? At Daves a while back. Poured an brownish Amber color with a small foamy tan head. Aroma/taste of tart cherry, red wine vinegar, toasted grain, and sour dark fruit. Sharp carbonation!

A simply ff-ing fantastic cherry and more sour. Beautiful sourness with great fruit flavors that never overwhelm.
Tap at the Tap Takeover at Oproer in 29-1-2017
750ml bottle. Dark amber brown pour. Bourbon nose up front with cherries. Taste follows, dry throughout with the wine barrel. Agressive, delicious.
I get cherries, with no sweetness, a bit of oak, and a bright, lemony tartness the entire way through. Dry, almost bitter aftertaste - but not in a way that clashes with the sourness. Very good.

Thanks Khalil for sharing the bottle! Poured into a taster showing unfiltered brown with white lacing. 

The nose shows light bourbon, oak, and lightly tart. 

The palate is medium bodied and lightly carbonated. Highly tart with flavors of bourbon but clashes severely with the red wine barrel and quite astringent.
At Jerrys LS. Sour, musty, very woody. Cherry and balsamic. Dry finish. Serving: Tap
Draft - pours dark brown tan head - nose and taste of sour caramel, funky earth and cherry vinegar - medium body

Pours deep, hazy burgundy with low pink head. Aroma of blackberry, red and black currant, etc... berry bomb! Taste is rich berry tart, almond icing and mild alcohol sweet in the finish. Light and smooth or crisp body depending on your mileage, average carbonation.
750 ml. bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with a decent beige head. Aroma of tart fruit, funk, and wood. Taste is tart cherries, dark fruit, funk, spice, and wood. Very good.

Draught. Pours an opaque murky brown with a fading light brown lacy head. Aroma is of cherries, blackcurrant, vinegar, acidic. Taste is of blackcurrant, cherries, dark grapes, acidic. Oily mouthfeel, dry finish, medium carbonation.

Another great soir from cascade, this one is quite tasty with a bit of metallic funk. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from a colleague. Black beer lasting tan head. Sour dark fruit and liquorice aroma. Some malt. Some sourness. Its a very drinkable well balanced sour beer. A touch of the balsamic vinegar. Yep a little sweetness from the ABV maybe. Some dark cherry flavour. Its decent. Just a little one dimensional.

2014 vintage. 3 oz pour at Hops & Pie. Deep reddish purple appearance with a light tan head. Aroma of dark fruit, sour cherries, red wine, light vanilla and funky sour notes. Similar flavor, moderately sour and vinous with light oak and a hint of bourbon spice. Medium body with a tart, puckering feel and a light oak finish. Delicious.

Bomber from Crafted in Haymarket, VA
Aroma: sour cherries, woody, bourbon, dark fruits, woody
Appearance: cloudy brown with a tan head
Taste: medium sourness, medium sweetness, 
Palate: medium body, average carbonation, slick feel, sour finish

Excellent

Bottle: Poured a deep red color ale with a nice large pink foamy head with OK retention and minimal lacing. Aroma of intense cherry notes with plenty of oak and tart/acidic notes are also discernable. Taste is also a mix of oak and tart cherry notes with very little residual sugar notes, some acidic flavours are also perceptible. Body si full for style with good carbonation. Very enjoyable take of the style but I would prefer a bit less acidity.
Bottle at home. Pours deep brown, nose is oak, cherry, toffee, vinegar, taste is tart, chewy toffee, oak, cherry, sweet, light balsamic.

Refrigerated 75 cl brown bottle corked and capped, 2014 project poured into a glass. Clear dark brown with small beige head. Aroma is sour vinegar, medium body, low carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is tart, some oak, some vinegar, and a little cherries.

On tap at the Cascade brewpub: 2014 version at 9.8% ABV in July 2016. 
Sour aroma with sour cherries and vague dark dried fruits. Nice complexity. 
Lovely dark ruby body with a lasting off-white head that leaves a draping of sticky lacing on the snifter. 
Moderate tartness. More cherry in the taste than the aroma.

 Overall: excellent version of the style.

Bottle. Little Leeds Beer House. Label states 2014 project. 9.8%. Clear, dark ruby red. Thin, dense, lasting, sticky, light tan head. Looks good. Nose has stewed cherry. Cherry pie. Booze soaked wood. Sour cherry. Some vanilla. Light cinnamon spice. Some bitter chocolate notes. On top of all that, theres a fusty, mouldy yeasty thing going on that sits just right. Taste has sweet and tart sourness in equal measure. A bit like like an old balsamic vinegar. Smooth palate. Light acidity. Lightly acidic, earthy, stone fruit finish. Very nice.
750ml bottle of 2014 Project. Pours a dark brown color with a bit of head. Mild sour and cherry flavor. Tobacco.

75cl bottle. Medium tan head atop crystal clear dark brown body. Aroma is moderately sweet, sour cherry, light funk. Taste is moderately sweet, sour cherry, light funk, grape, light wood. Medium body, light stickiness, alcohol well concealed.
750ml bottle pours out a cola color topped with a small head. nose is fruit barrel notes cherries funky tartness. taste is more of the cherries barrel pucker tartness.

Bottle purchased at Red Apron/B Side. Poured a very dark brown color with a small, but long lasting tan head. Aroma was some very dark mild bourbon notes, which become stronger as it warms. Vinous notes are very prominent. Nice oud bruin character to this one.

March 12, 2016 - on tap at Rare Beer Fest held in the Minnesota History Center. Orangish red pour with limited head. Like the Noyaux, this was nicely balanced with the fruit, wood and wine, but also had a nice bourbon flavor mixed in.
@ Cascade 16-3-9: Trevlig syrlighet med fina fattoner och en mycket fin balans. Lång eftersmak.
On tap at Cascade. Dark amber with a small head. Cherries, funk, bourbon, oak and some vinegar. The finish was dry and tart.

Pours deep burgundy with a light brown laced with violet head. Aroma is cherries, blackberries, slight spice and some oak. Taste is cherry sour, cherry sweet, cinnamon, sight spices, oak, blackberry tart, medium-high acidity, tart cranberry.

Had this on closing night of the Amsterdam Cafe in San Francisco...a casualty of Tenderloin gentrification. This beer was recommended to me by Bay Area beer guru, Douglas Smith, who like me, cut his teeth on wine. Feel extremely lucky to have heard his discourse on corks, bottle caps, and micro-oxidation at a bottle share with a Speakeasy Syndicate vertical. Needless to say, the recommendation more than panned out.

Sampled at the Societe Party 2016. It poured a dark brown color with a tan head. The aroma was puckery with cherry, oak and vanilla. The taste was similar to the aroma with more cherry, oak, roast and vanilla. Very nice.
Bottle drank at Cotteridge Wines tasting room; clear dark copper pour with a creamy light tan head, aroma has light bourbon, mellow funk, dark vinous fruits, tart cherries, mellow bourbon.

75cl bottle at home. It pours a dark copper / brown color with ruby edges and a minimal tan head. Aroma is strong acidic and light funk with wine esters balsamic vinegar strawberries melon lemon and funk. Taste is also acidic an deep oaky complex with notes of wood vanilla balsamic vinegar lemon juice and tart raisins. Medium bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, great beer

Bottle shared with koleminer20 and Gus for his birthday. 2014 vintage. Aroma is tart cherry, barrel, whiskey, sour, funk, skins, lots of red wine, yowza. Appearance is red and dark brown, light tan head, pretty hazy. Taste immediate tart cherry, red wine, followed by barrel, skins, funk, very layered, very good. Mouthfeel is medium body, crisp carbonation, lots of wine in the aftertaste. Overall, yowza. Quite quite good.

Bottle. Pours a near clear deep amber brown with a tan head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma is very acid forward with strong sour cherries, a bit of wine dryness and a bit of bourbon. Flavor has sour cherry throughout with a bit of earthiness, some dry wine and a hint of bourbon.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2016 Fantastic aroma of oaky dark fruit and lactic sour. So complex. Fig, raisin, oak, almost a mild Woody cherry. Taste is lactic sour, maybe 5 or 6 of 10, very balanced and not overly sour for cascade beers. Dark, and almost a dry finish. Woody dark fruit flavors give enough balance to the sour. Flavors of fig, raisin, oak and slight sweet with some vanilla bourbon, the bourbon Woody flavors are so balanced and not boozy at all. A slight tannic Woody finish. That is the only slight negative to this beer, it is almost like it aged a bit too long and got too woody? But that is a slight negative ( having this again and do not feel it is too Woody, so I would remove that as a slight negative and am bumping from4.7 to 4.8. It is so complex and just great) . It is so complex and a great sour. Really good. Read on the bottle after the fact that it is aged on Bing cherries. The cherry flavors I get from it tasted like they were all from the wood. Sugars all fermented away and really intermingled with the oak. Very good. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle pour at BCS. Thanks to BCS staff for sharing! Clearish blood copper with almost no head. Big funky nose with lots of oak, cherry, hay and barnyard notes. Active carbonation and fruit-forward on the palate with big fruit notes that come out as it warms. Very aggressive tartness, but not quite sour as the oak really mellows out the tartness. Some light oaky vanilla notes as it warms as well. Finish is tart and dry with cherry and almond. Awesome!

Bottle. Hazy deep copper liquid with small to medium off-white head. Aroma of lemon, citrus, toffee, bread, toffee and caramel. Taste is dry and medium sour with notes of grapefruit, lemon, light grain and red apples. Medium bodied with medium carbonation.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with no head. Aroma and taste are great, perfect amount of tart, sour, and wood.

Bottle shared at RBScSG in Gothenburg. Pours ugly murky yellowish dark brown with a small creamy beige head that leaves some spotty trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is sour and malty with dark bread, sourdough crackers, lemon juice, hay, moist soil, vanilla, moist wood, charries, balsamic vinegar and lemon zest. Taste is sweet, sour, malty and fruity. mouthfeel is round, tart, tiny dry, throat burning acetic and medium bodied. Finish is sweet and sour with dark bread, sourdough crackers, caramel, lemon juice, cherries, raspberries, dark grapes, hay, moist soil, moist wood, balsamic vinegar, barnyard and lemon zest. Too acetic and very hard to drink...
On tap at the brewery. Sweet and spicy aroma. Flavor is slightly sour with some caramel flavor. Good beer.

2014 Project. 750 bottle. Mucky brown with lite lacing. Funky fruity tobacco nose with mellow sour cherries. Starts out tart, but not strong, more sour cherries with vinous and wood character. Soft sourness in the finish. Bourbon and alcohol seem to be absent.

Bottle from online store. Pours a deep brown with a light tan head. Aromas of oak, dark fruit, sour cherry. Taste is semi dry and tart. Flavors of cherry, darker fruit, oak, barrel. Good. Lingering tartness on the finish.
Tap at the barrel house. Reddish brown pour with a clingy dense head. Red wine and wood, hint of bourbon, sour cherry. Yummy.

Taster at the brewery. Mahogany/brown with a light tan head and thin lace. Aromas of bourbon, dark fruit, oak, alcohol and tobacco. Sour taste dominates, featuring dark fruit, oak, bourbon. Medium bodied, gentle carbonation, creamy mouthfeel and warming alcohol in the finish. Bit too boozy.

Pours dark brown into a snifter with a thin tan head. Aroma of cherries, oak, whiskey.

Pleasantly tart in the flavor. Taste mirrors the aroma, with a hint of vanilla, Im assuming from the whiskey barrels. 

This is one damn delicious beer.
Sample at Decatur Beer Fest. Nice dark sour. Good tartness and high on that spectrum. Little bit of purple fruit to round it out a bit. Good body and light oakiness.

Poured into a tulip. 2011 vintage.

3.75 A: Pours a deep plum color. Some yeasties hanging out at the bottom of the glass. One finger of frothy beige head. Retention is about average and a half finger of lacing is left.

3.75 S: Well, this definitely has some cherries in it. Big, bold, beautiful cherries. Tart and delicious. Im not detecting much bourbon at this point, but the barrel itself is quite present lending a soft tannic woodiness. Not much funk as this more showcases tartness and sour punches. Nice acetic acidity. Toastiness, mixed berries, sour plum, and a touch of lemon. 

3.75 T: This pretty much mirrors the nose. Big, bold cherry. Moderate sour tanginess with plenty of tartness. Lemon, plum, black and blueberries. Toastiness, touch of neutral maltiness. Bit of earthy funk.

3.75 M: Medium body. Good moderate carbonation with a light spritziness. Super smooth with a tart finish.

4.00 D: Very good beer. Didnt get much bourbon, but thats probably a good thing since it didnt need any other flavors.

★ 1,054 characters


DavoleBomb, Aug 15, 2014

Hazy brown colour, off-white head. Aroma of red fruits, vinegar, berries and caramel. Sour flavour, sweet caramel, nail polish remover. Sour finish, red berries.(from 75cL bottle @ Lets drink all of Richs American beers Tasting. Thanks for sharing, omgrich!)

At Richs Massive Cellar Emptying Tasting. 2012 Sang Noir 9.8% a brown with a dash of red. A rich plum, figs & prunes aroma. Tart, cork, light fruitiness and a raspy dry carbonation. A bit oaky maple woodsy barrel charcter. Alright.

Bottle, 2011 project thanks to cocoapuph. Pours clear ruby hazel, small tan head, decent lacing. Initial aroma is quite acetic, mellowing somewhat to reveal cherries, roasted malts, lemon, oak tannins, nail polish remover, and sherry. Flavor is medium tart, tartness really comes on late, puckering after a bit. Somewhat roasty, cherry notes, vinous and oaky, some nail polish remover but less than in the nose. Medium body, lingering tartness. Not bad, not great either.
sour cherries, not much head, very dark, red colour, very spritzy, very sour lingering finish, there is an interesting mushroom je ne sais quoi underlying the cherries. really liked it
Bottle - Vintage 2011 - Lots of red grape and raisin with a touch of vinegar. Cloudy brown with a decent beige head. Acidic, tart red grape with a bit of balsamic. Not bad for the age.

Bottle (2011) to taster
Some diacetyl, grape, lemon. Dark, translucent red, with a bubbly ringed head. Taste is red grape, acid, tart cherry.

Dégustée chez Alexandre Mathieu. Cheers buddy! La bière est brune, opaque et délaissée de toute mousse. Le nez de cette bière ne ma pas emballé, contrairement aux autres produits Cascade qui présentent des arômes beaucoup plus près des fruits qui ont servi au brassage. Celle-ci présente en fait un nez acétique, vinaigré, boisé, mince. Je naurais jamais pu deviner la présence de cerises. En bouche lalcool et le bois occupent presque toute la place. On sent que lacidité nest pas quattribuable au bois mais à une cerise bien jeune mais timide. Finale sèche, cette bière ne figure pas parmi mes préférées de cette dégustation.

Bottle at Grand Tasting, RBSCSG 2015 cons 2015-07-11 Göteborg
ABV: 9,345%
AR: vinos, tart, sour lemonade
AP: dark hazy brown, no head
F: sour gooseberries, vineager, lemon flesh, tart
Sample at RBScSG. 2011 Project. Dark amber with off white head. inegar, hay, oak in smell. Taste is lactic, vinegar, tart, oak. Dry and sour, medium carbonation.

Bottle at Grand Tasting, RBSCSG 2015 in Gothenburg. Dark amber/brown beer with a small beige head. Sour grapefruit and vinegar aroma, hay, tart, figs,funky, lactic notes. Sourish vinegar flavor, raisins, grapefruit, floral, figs, tart notes.

2012 project. Pours a murky copper from the bomber with thin ring of tan head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of big tart dark fruit and vanilla oak. Taste is tart cherries and lactic acidity, boozy and big, burns of sour and booze on the way down. Really good, but really intense.
A perfect sour with nice bourbon and pinot noir coming out. Very great beer!

Bottle at home. Pours dark brown with a quickly dissapearing off-white head. Aroma is quite lactic, with notes of roasted barley and dark forest fruit. Medium body, low on sweetness, high on sourness, kind of rough through the fruit sours as well. Taste is yoghurt with blackberries, tart cherries and raspberries.

2011 bottle
Brown/amber pour. Head dissipated quicky. Oak and bourbon nose with a candied cherry infiltration. Nice balance of vanilla, boozy oak, cherries, malt. All flavors mesh very well. I like now just as much as the first time I had it a few years ago. Nice sour that doesnt rip the enamel off your teeth. Among, with bourbonic plague this might be my favorite cascade

On tap at the Barrel House on 3/16/15. Garnet brown in color with a decent sized beige head. Aroma is super funky and tart with notes of dried cherries, berry, and plum. Taste is of cherry, heavy funk, hay, red wine, and wood.

75cl bottle @Dangerous Bottleshares 7.0 thanks to Bursprak. Pours a dark reddish brown with a small, white head. Aroma has tobacco, cola, sweet candy cherry, and yeah.. cherry cola or doctor pepper or something. Taste is very tart and highly carbonated up front, followed by a long line of taste impressions; more sweetness and some cherries, and ends off with a sour/sweet cherry candy thingy and some oaky bourbonlike notes. No alcohol presence! Definitely some similarities to Duchesse de Bourgogne, but more elegant and with some caramel. Pretty high carbonation and medium full body.

Bottle @ Dangerous Bottle Share 7.0. Thanks Aaron! Brown murky pour with red hues and small lacings. Nose has tobacco, dark cherries, acidic notes and some vanilla. Taste is sweet and sour, again tobacco, oaky notes, sweet vanilla. Sparkling carbonation. So complex and looong finish. ABV is completely hidden.

Bottle shared @ the ever awesome dangerous bottleshare #7 . Pours dark brown with red shadows. Very short lasting head. Aroma of deep ripe cherries, cherry candy, tobacco, dr. pepper/cherry coke, balsamic notes and some oak. Nice and interesting aroma. The taste has some sour candied cherries, balsamic, oak, dry wood and some red berries and dark fruits. The alcohol is very absent.

Shared at Dangerous Bottleshare #7. Pours dark brown with a shortlasting brown head. Some reddish notes. Aromas of dark sweet cherries, tobacco, gunpowder, cherri coke, vanilla, balsamico. Taste is pretty tart up front, sour cherry candy, tobacco, vanilla, oak, caramel, coke, vinegar, balsamico. Not bad, Cascade. Not bad at all!

[2/25/15] Draught at Cascade Brewing Barrel House in Portland. As Cascade Sang Noir. Dark brown with a beige head. Sourish aroma of spicy wood, dark fruits, a bit of vanilla, red wine, cobwebs and a musty cellary character. Sour flavor with a light sweetish note, with white, dark fruits, spicy wood and some vanilla, a bit puckering. Medium-bodied. Very nice.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2015 14/II/15 - 1Pt.6Fl. Oz. bottle @ RBBWG IV (Beerlover_Bens place) - BB: n/a (2015-211) Thanks to JefVerstraete for sharing the bottle!
Clear dark brown beer, small irregular beige head, little stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: chloride, sour, funky, more chloride. MF: lots of carbon, medium body. Taste: very sour, lemony, some vinegar, chloride, very unpleasant kind of sourness. Aftertaste: vinegar, stomach acid (so I dont have to write down "puke"), lemony, sourish, little bitter, chloride, unpleasant sourness. Cascade really isnt my thing, it seems.
Mahogany pour, big offwhite head. Tart cherry aroma with boozy and fruity notes, flavor of tart cherry and dark fruits.
Tap at Cascade Brewing, Portland. Vintage 2012. Colour is slightly cloudy brown with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, berries, wood and soft sourness.

Bottle at RBBWG 2015 shared by JefVerstraete. Brown, very fruity, malts, nice sour. Very decent dark sour.Earlier Rating: 2/14/2015 Total Score: 3.7Bottle at RBBWG shared by JefVerstraete. Spur brown, vinegar, acid, malts. Nice stuff.
Bottle from a trade. Many thanks Kump! Shared @ RBBWG 2015. Dark brown, thin head. Aroma of vinegar, red berries, sour fruit. Notes of lime. Light sweet, tart aftertaste. Good.

Thanks to JefVerstraete! 750 ml. bottle sampled @ RBBWG IV.Dark brown, little head. Nose is vingar, sour red fruit, puckering in USA fashion. Taste is brown sugar, puckering, sour red fruits vinegar, sour malt, lots of puckering oak, sour black cherries, fruit skins. Rather thick body. Very nice beer, very satisfactory sour in the USA tradition.
Bottle @ RBBWG 2015 shared by JefVerstraete. Opaque brownish color, medium sized off-white to beige head. Smell and taste malts, sour red fruits, superb red fruits in there. Very fresh.
Ruby red pour with light tan head and lace. Aroma is sour with fruitiness. Flavor is dry sour/tart with some fruity esters. Medium bodied but a tad fizzy for me.
UPDATED: JAN 14, 2015 2012 Bottle pour split at home, dark amber color, strong sour aroma. Bourbon aged sour with a little cherry taste (just as advertised) if you love sours this is a beer for you.

750 mL bottle split. 2012 project. Always a treat to pop open a bottle from these guys. Pours a beautiful tinted purple black color with a swirling beige head. Red grapes, cherry, and just a touch of bourbon in the aroma. Probably only noticed the bourbon because I knew it was there. Huge, pucker up sour flavor right up front. Creamy sour fruit body with grapes, black cherries, and berry. Some slight dusty oak flavor as well coming through in the finish. Gives it the perfect aged feel to it, which compliments any great sour. Long, drawn out cherry and grape finish. Just keeps getting better too as I go. What an incredible beer this is, though I expected nothing less from one of the best. The price tag might scare some people off of a beer like this, but they continue to prove to me that it is well worth it. Awesome stuff to say the least.

750ml bottle, thanks to caterwaul for sharing. 2012 project. Labeled 9.8%. Dark brown red color, kind of hazy. Thin light brown head. Loose bits of lace. Great vinous aroma, dark fruit, oaky, kind of spicy, very light touch of acetic. Bigger body. Smooth, kind of crisp lighter carbonation, lightly slick. Moderate to bigger sweet taste, nice moderate sour taste. Very tasty big dark sour. Pleasure to sip on slowly. Very pleasant interesting kind of subtle yet noticeable barrel aroma.

From notes. This was shared at a tasting put on by @mikem409 on November 7. Shared by tectactoe. Thanks! The pour is a dark, dark orangey brown color with a light tan head that disappears to a collar rather quickly. The aroma is incredibly tart and sour. There is some cherry and lemon, There is a little funkiness to it on the deep inhale, but ifs really good. The flavor is fantastic. The tart cherries are just beautiful. There is a little sweetness, almost like its a juice. There is a decent amount of acidity to it, but I love it. The mouth feel is very good. medium-bodied with a nice carbonation and a very dry, tart, sour cherry going on for quite some time. Its a beautiful beer
Good but weird sour. Can't say I gravitated towards it but enjoyed it at cascade brewery

Bottle, 2011 project. Pours an orangey garnet, slightly muddy with small tan head. Aroma is really nice: spiritous, with lots of spicy bourbon and port mingling with roasted sweet cherry, sour pie cherry, curaçao, plums, tobacco, lemon zest, oak. Taste is sour orange and prunes with sharp sour cherry, vermouth, and an underlying caramel sweetness as well as light notes of milk chocolate. Long oaky sweet/sour finish. Great complexity, great beer.

Keg at Cascade Barrel House, as Sang Noir, 11/11/14.
Murky mahogany brown with moderate tan edgeing.
Nose is funky, musty wood, bitter fruit rinds, horse blanket qualities, tarte red berry skins.
Taste comprises dank wood, nutty concept, funk, dirt, musty red berry, cherry skins, off red grapes, light dry rot.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Decent well balanced Flemish red with light puckerings.

text: Bottle: 2012 Project. Dont know what took me so long to get around to this bottle, but Im glad it is finally time. Slightly muddy brown, opaque body with hints of ruby throughout. Muddled, light-tan head forms a flimsy collar on top within moments. Super tart, sour lactic aroma... Cherry skins, lemon, cherry flesh, sour redcurrant, tannic oak just on the edge of boozy vinousness, a hint of musty funk, cotton, mild yogurt quality, & a small hint of spice towards the finish, almost like cinnamon. I get that note quite often from rich, cherry beers. Flavor full of tart cherry juice. Theres a small, offsetting sweetness underneath, but make no mistake, this thing is TART as hell. Mild acidity, especially compared to most of Cascades offerings. Faint vanilla yogurt, sour lacto yeast, lemon skins, currants, wet oak, faint grape skin, & a small touch of booze in the finish. Lingering acidic cherry skins on the palate with a touch of tannin. Very well done.

Had ontap at the barrel house served in a taster. Plum ruby hue, cream Hued head with lots of lacing. Nose is of cherry, figs, plums, leather. Slight white wine appears. Sourness is on the back end followed by light acid burn in the throat. Pretty dang exciting right?

Tap at Cascade Brewing. Pours brown with orange hues and light tan head. Aroma of vanilla, bourbon, wine, cherries, sour yeast. Taste is light sour, lots of wine, crisp, lots of complex layers, great long finish. Overall, very good.,

Courtesy of tectactoe
Bottle: The aroma consists of moderate-heavy cherries (lightly tart), yogurt, light vinegar, lemon, hints of vanilla, and oak. It pours hazy brownish-orange with a minimal beige head that quickly fades to a very fine ring. The flavor starts with a moderate dose of sweet and sour cherry with a touch of cola. The finish has moderate sour lemon and a touch of oak. Its medium bodied moderate-lively carbonation.

"This ones a wild ale all the way. As with Sang Royale, the awesomeness of this brew cannot be understated. Pinot, whiskey, and sour cherry? Why yes please. Easily the winner from a pretty impressive line-up of sours."
Bottle. Brown pour with tan head. Dark fruit, sweet tones, funk and aromas. Cherry, dark tart fruit, funk and cascade normal tones.
Bottle. Pours mahogany with a beige head. Sour berries, sharp acetic notes, sherry, and an overly acidic finish. A bit much; fine for a small pour, but relatively low drinkability.

Pours a cola color with no head/carbonation. Aromas of cherry and chocolate with a slight balsamic reduction note. The sour is almost too overpowering. Slight cherry and grapes flavor come through but mostly acidic. Good but not great. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Big, bold cherry. Moderate sour tanginess with plenty of tartness. Lemon, plum, black and blueberries. Toasties and a little funk.
Med brown and a bit dull, barrel, touch acetic, sweet demerara character, nice balance.
Poured from the tap. Reddish brown with beige head. Very Pinot noir taste, mild vinegar.

On tap at the barrel house. Heavy port aroma, cherry balsamic reduction, molasses, chocolate covered raisins. Flavor is tart tropical fruits, guava and passionfruit, drenched in port reduction. Fruitcake and chocolate and stewed cherries.

750ml bottle care of Elise. 2012 Project. Deep murky grey dark brown-red, almost purple tints. Initial head fades out but the sides stay bubble thanks to the lively carbonation bubbles ever-rising. Sort of harsh acetone-vinegar sourness. Some pleasant sour cherry tones. Leathery bourbon caramel...mild, but adds some nice depth. No finesse in the sour, just hits you over the head. This beer is probably best in 5 oz samples...in no way sessionable, sort of a task, albeit an enjoyable task, to drink. A great concept, Cascade just doesnt succeed in subtlety.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy dark brown, pretty dark. Tan head. Aroma of dark fruits and sourness. Hint of cherry too. Dont get bourbon barrel, but sour. Taste is tart, feel it in my jowels. Lots if tart cherries, abv is well hidden. Get some sweetness in the taste too. Really nice balance of sour and sweet.

Bottle share thanks to beechner224. Dark brown pour with light brown creamy lasting head. Big sour, acidic, cherry, oaky, vanilla aroma. Sour, tart, lots of cherry notes, light roasty malt character, more of the barrel ones through here too. Tasty, well balanced, nice.
Red brown pour at Cascade barrel house. Aroma of sour cherries. Taste is tart and acidic. Very tasty!

(bottle - corked & caged 750 ml - 2012 vintage) Dark copper pour with a thin tan head. Sour and tart funk in the aroma with a hint of cherries and sweetness. Nice sour and tart flavor at the start that gives way to a sweet fruity and cherry middle and you can definitely get hints of the barrel. Not so sour that it overpowers and really does well with the sweetness.

Tap at brewery. Dark reddish brown pour. Port wine, cherries, leather, oak, caramel. Medium to full body. Well balanced where it is not too oaky and you can actually feel the cherries and other fruit. Very nice

On tap at the brewpub - Pours dark brown with a tannish head. The aroma has rich cherries, dark caramel, oak, pie filling, oak, pedio / lactic sourness and quick rich and malty. It has a full smooth rich body with really soft carbonation. The flavor begins with rich berries, vanilla, oak, bourbon, tobacco, dark fruits, berries, toffee and caramel. The finish has lots of malt, barrel and fruit. Really nice.

Pours a very nice dark red. Smell is all bourbon and cherries. A tiny hint of oak. Pretty awesome. Taste is pretty tart. Bourbon mostly in the front and back end. Just enough cherry. Overall a great beer.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
Draft taster at the brewery. Brown copper color. Aroma of oak bourbon barrel and cherry, with leather. Medium light sourness. Average carbonation. Pretty good.

Draught @ Cascade, Portland, OR


Pours dark reddish brown with a smooth head. Aroma of wood, oak, bourbon, vinous notes, tart berries and yeast. Taste is tart, sourish and woody with loads of bourbon, berries and red wine. Finish is malty, tart and woody with some oak, bourbon and berries. Quite complex and tasty.
Bottle. Pours dark amber with an off white head. Aroma is toasted oak, cherries, a rouch of mold. Tart, acetic base with dark cherry. Vanilla oak in the finish.
Deep dark color. Nice aroma. First Sip Is Smooth Then Can Taste Sour And Alcohol After taste. Nice beer.
Murky reddish pour. Big bourbon, sweet and tart cherry, oak, very nutty finish.

bomber shared. poured a murky brown color with white head. got the funky and bourbon on the nose immediately..the flavor was quite tasty I do love me a red flanders but a double on bourbon barrel and more funky...the cherry come out in this one as well...solid flavors throughout...another great sour from cascade.

Pours dark brown with good head and lacing. Plum and some citrus, comes together well with some Belgian yeast. Bretta. Light to medium tart finish. Good stuff. Bottle thanks to GEV46 at Epic Sour Tasting.
From a bottle shared at the DC Epic Sour Beer Tasting. Thanks GEV46! Pours a murky brown with a tan head. Flavors of tart caramel apple and sour cherries.
750 ml bottle pours a ruby brown with a tan head. Tart cherry and slight bourbon taste.

On tap. 

A: Dark red bordering on mahogany. Fluffy, foamy creme colored head. 

N: Bourbon and pinot. Leather and grapes. Lemon rind. Caramel mixed with fruit, but not as pleasant at that sounds. Too much bourbon, not enough noir.

T: Sour lactic acid and overly sweet bourbon. Nothing works in concert.

M: Oily and heavy. Too much body. 

O: I used to really enjoy this at the Holiday Ale Festival. In the midst of all those stouts and bourbon beers, it was a break. This is not. In the cold light of day, its not at all sensible.

This pours a dark plum color. A very tart all around beer. Very good. A big vinegar flavor. A lot of tart fruits, cherries and black cherries mixed with some deep oak flavors. I really like all of its flavors. Maybe I was just feeling it but maybe the best for me for the night of some good stuff. Really great brewery.

Draft at the brewpub. Pours a deep reddish brown color with a tan head and some lacing. Aroma is chocolate covered cherries, a little vanilla, a little oak. Medium on the palate with light carbonation. Flavor is lightly sour, some bourbon, oak, vanilla, cherry, transitions into red wine, with a dry, red wine finish. Excellent.

Poured from tap to glass. Deep dark red hue with tan head that dissipated to a moderate ring. Aroma is lactic, bright cherries, acetic, sugar, soft wood. Mouthfeel is great with a light body and good carbonation. Taste is sharp dryness initially, followed by a sour tartness, and a dry tartness with faint woody astringentness in the finish. Overall this is a fantastic Flanders. It is quite tart/sour with a nice complexity of lactic, acetic, and tartness.
Good sour beer. I like Bruery Sours more. Has a light cherry flavor with some funk and acidic sourness. Great carbonation level, pours cloudy reddish brown

Bottle generously shared at the Pre-Hunahpu Thursday Tasting. Pours a deep ruby/ maroon color with a white head. Nose is big vinegar, balsamic, oak, cherries, tart fruit, oak, and slight vanilla. Flavor is similar with vinegar, oak, cherries, tart fruit, and light vanilla. Very nice sour overall.

Bottle. Nearly black but still clearly a brown hue with a nice foamy light tan head. Some barrel and bourbon notes at first in the aroma, slight fruit sweetness, some wordiness, slightly sweet sour notes as well. Flavor is deep and rich, with slight bourbon, some toffee, present unripe fruit sourness to finish in the flavor. Medium soft and velvety body. Well balanced.

Bottle at EBF, 3/22/14Very nice pour, obviously bottle conditioned, unfiltered, etc...Moderately hazy chocolate-auburn body is topped by a medium-beige head showing moderate retention.Quite lactic in the nose with what is either just a very sharp, concentrated acidity, or more likely, some bitter, dry, roasted barley acidity. Some more vibrancy is added to the nose via some light cherry-like fruitiness, though it itself is quite tart keeping things quite intensely tart/sour/dry. A touch of caramel malt-like sweetness is slightly noticeable with more warming and there is certainly a little too much booziness at this level of dryness.Until reading this description, I didnt realize this was intended as a Flemish sour, actually just paying attention to the "noir in the name and taking it to be a stout-like sour. I thought the flavors really supported this notion, as its definitely got some burnt character to it, a little bit of chocolate and none of the very boisterous red fruit character I associate with Flemish sours, whether fruited or not. There is certainly acetic acid here, but its leaner and tempered with a balsamic, nearly coffee-like note.  So yes, a bit muddled in the flavor, as I always find dark sours to be, with the roastiness kind of at odds with the brett, though less so the lactic elements. Very nice mouthfeel, however, lightly slick, but with plenty of tight carbonation and not overattenuated (nor under). A bit dirty/yeasty tasting at times.  Alcohol not as evident in the flavor as in the nose.
Awesome red sour ale, on tap at the brewery in portland, barrel aged, delciious

Sample from 2011 bottle at Kurtkeller 006: Cascade-tastic 01 on 02/21/2014. The beer is a hazy ruby-brown color with a medium fluffy white head that recedes quickly to a wispy film. Strings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of oak, cherries and yeast. Medium to full body with flavors of semi-tart cherries, vinous oak and earthy yeast. The finish is fruity with a lingering boozy cherry aftertaste. Very good all around.

750ml bottle, shared with friends. Somehow never rated this. Time for that to change, as at $25/bottle im not likely to buy many more of these. Pours opaque, deep dark purple red. Aroma: cherries, red vines, vanilla, oak, and more cherries, vinegar. Taste: sweet cherries and oak up front, nice tart backside, cherries well integrated. Lively carbonation, medium-full body, creamy slick texture. Overall: cherry red vines. A little char and vanilla. A well-integrated, classic cascade.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2014 Bottle (2012) shared by ajax25g, poured into a tulip. Pours a dark brown/amber with a frothy light tan/off-white head. Aromas of oak, tart fruit, vinegar, light bourbon. Tasting notes of bourbon, oak, vinegar, cherries, dark fruit. Medium body with a dry finish. 8/4/8/4/17

Bottle (2011) shared at DC Annual Epic Sour Tasting, thanks GEV46! Hazy brown with off-white head. Aromas of vinegar, dark fruit, tart fruit. Tasting notes of vinegar, tart fruit, puckering sour notes. Medium body with a dry finish. 8/4/9/4/18
Bottle from Alex, 600th rating, pours reddish brown with low head. Nice tart and dark fruit aroma and light barrel, nice tart and semi sweet finish, great flanders

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2014 At c&g tasting. Aroma is cherry strawberry oak, medium acidity. Taste is nice punch of strawberry tartness flavor that ends quickly and clean. 3.8

Had at the BGoA Winter tasting. Pours dark brown. Aroma is sour and funky. Somewhat sweet finishes dry. Nice beer.
Delicious, sour vinous aroma. Sour, way sour but great. Tangy, funky finish. Bottle from a mystery donor @ the drowland-Tallahassee Winter Homecoming 2014 @ Proof.

3 ounce sample at The Davis Beer Shoppe. 2011 vintage. Aroma has a nice tart funkiness present with light underlying roasted malts, too. Light sweet chocolate is also in there. Really nice. Scantly hazy dark amber body with a medium light tan head present. Fair lacing. Starts with a light chocolate sweetness before this becomes vinous and tart and acidic. Light roast flavors linger. Well-balanced. Really good stuff.

On tap at the barrel house 
Dark amber with a small beige head and some lacing. Aroma of toasted malts, caramel and woody. Flavors of cherries, woody, tart with a dry finish  
Nice

Draft at 16 Tons Taphouse, Eugene. Pours a deep reddish brown, no head and slightly translucent. Barrels and a tart funkiness strong in the nose. Lacto. Body medium tart with a strong woody character in the finish, lingering vinous notes. Near perfection.
Aroma: coffee. It pours a dark brown colour with a 1 finger of off white mousse head. Medium carbonation. Beautiful lacing. It tastes like a belgian beer mixed w some stout.

Dark pour at the Racoon lodge. 

Dark color, off-white head. Cherry dominates the aroma. The flavor is something special: rich dark cherries with cherry skins/pits, tannic but not the balsamic thing that comes up too heavy in many Flemish reds. Throat-warming but more from the acidity than the alcohol which otherwise is quite subdued. Super beer.

04AUG12 - on draft at barrel house.

Pretty purple ale with some light pink surface bubbles. Up front in the nose for me are the bing cherries and pinot notes. Nice and full bodied with a hint of ink and cassis. Some hints of alcohol and oak alongside leather and sweat. I like the already. The flavor carries more of the grape than Id anticipated - refined, plummy and juicy. A bit of booze (maybe whiskey..) comes through just in the back end, but as an accent and overture - really nice. Medium bodied with moderate on hi carb. I like this beer - just ordered four bottles.

Serving type: on-tap

On tap at the Cascade Raccoon Lodge. Dark red with slight head. Tart aroma with cherries and fruit. Flavor is tart, sweet, cherry. Nicely carbonated, and medium body. Sour finish. Very nice with lots and lots of flavor.

Aroma: Deep Mahognany Grape, Deep Red Wine

Appearance: Redddish Hue, Passes Mild Light, Thin Brown Head Ring, Some Lacing

Pours a hazy reddis brown with almost no head unless that small rim counts. Aroma is really fruity with cherries dominating. There is also a bourbon "feel" to it. Taste is tart and lactic without too much acetic acid (in my glass at least). It was still plenty acid though. Light bodied. I seem to have enjoyed it a lot more than my tasting partners, I will have to revisit.

bottle @ cascade + upright tasting sessions - coz were porks. pours unclear burgundy with a small off-white head, some retention and lacing. grape juice, sweet and boozy cherries, very citric and also acetic, woodsy and earthy cherry stones, pepper and spices. moderate carbonation, light to medium body - oily, slightly harsh vinegar and peppery finish. meh. field pour.

750 ml bottle shared with Tom and chums. Pours a hazy ruby red with a short lived white head. Aroma is cherry, dimetapp cough syrup and welchs grape juice. Flavor is welchs grape juice, red cherries, green apple. Sour candy, tart, lemoney finish. Lingering tartness and lemon flavor. Light to medium body, sticky mouthfeel, weak to average carbonation. Robust, but good.

Bottle (750 ml). Shared by mathieuc, thanks! Hazy burgundy with a low beige head and little lacing. Aroma is of red fruits, oak, vinegar, ketchup, sweetness notes and malt. Taste is moderately sweet with a burst of ketchup, followed by red fruits, oak, malt and light spiciness. Medium body. Low to moderate carbonation. Dry mouthfeel. Tasted alongside 10 other Cascade bottles and it was definitely the less good. Miles away from Rodenbach. Too much ketchup.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours brown/red with almost no head. Aroma is of fruits, acid, sweetness, cherries. Taste is of cherries, intense acidity, fruits. Palate: Ligth-medium body. Overall: Good. Lots of cherries, but too much acetic to be outstanding.

Bottle from Tom10101, thanks a lot! Pour is hazy burgundy with little beige head. Aroma of tart cherries, oak (lots of tannins from the oak), vanilla. Taste has tart cherries, acetic, vanilla, wine, bourbon, some booze. Low-med body and soft carbonation. A big mess, struggled with this one. Drain pour

Pours muddy, red-brown with a frothy, off-white foam head. Tangy berry aroma, cherries, light booze. Big tart flavor with light sweetness, stones, grape skins. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Moderately dry on the finish with strong tartness, fine woody notes, fruits, heavy acidity. Very good stuff.

750 ml bottle courtesy of a trade with OregonHopMonster. The trade that keeps giving. Pours a deep brownish rusty reddish dark hue. Good haziness, copper glow on the bottom and edges. Frothy tannish head atop is firmly sized, dies to a ringer that laces ok. Aromas show distinct black cherry, cherry pits and skin. A bit of dark fruit, oak, and gentle red wine. Big black cherry, some lactic twang starts to grow as it warms. Sour lemony elements, yogurt, oak. A bit of biscuity and darker malt, plum and a bit of raisin. Black cherry bomb. Wet oak, touches of Bourbon and vanilla, gentle bit of spirit. Pretty intriguing. Initial is medium bodied, firm sour cherry element, lactic acidity, lemon and pitty fruit, dark fruit, some whiskey and vanilla oak elements work into the fold. Well blended, firm sourness keeps pushing into the middle, a bit of whiskey and oak take some lead. A bit of biscuit and reddish carmelized malt toastiness. Seedy cherries and cherryskin, lactic acidity, no real vinegar or balsamic presence though. The Bourbon elements sound like theyd be offensive or overwhelming but on this particular sour they really do work. Firmly lactic, zingy and black cherry. Not hot or ABV offensive. The Bourbon element truly is interesting, well integrated, and works really well to my surprise. Quite a unique beer here and one of the best darker Bourbon influenced sours Ive ever had. The cherries really flow, are potent, the barrel integrates well without being obnoxious. Well done.

Terrific sour, maybe the best of the Cascades Ive had. Murky brownish pour with reddish tints, and a nice spritzy carbonation. Very fine aroma, with tart cherries, deep oaky complexity, balsamic, and some understated candy sweetness too. Mouthfeel is lively, with a moderately acetic feel on the palate, but neither element is overdone. Flavors are if anything even more complex than the nose, with the barrel slightly more prominent in ways that coax more dark fruit character and sweetness. Tartness and brightness are still there, and everything integrates very well. Very fine sour.

Bottle shared by pmoney. Served in a FFF teku.

A: Pours a dark ruby color with a light tan head forming on the pour. It recedes to at thin ring that leaves some soapy lace behind.

S: Tart cherries with some light hints of bourbon. Sharp vinegar aspect to it with a oak barrel as well. Medium sweetness from malts run across the nose.

T: Cherry pie filling with tart cherry skins. Lactic sourness with some zingy vinegar notes. Sweet barrel finish with a combination of oak, vanilla and light bourbon.

M: Medium to light bodied, alcohol is well hidden with a zingy finish.

O: Sort of like a black cherry warhead in a sense with a less intense sour pucker. Zingy and tart with some sweetness from the barrel. Nice beer.

Serving type: bottle

Huge thanks to Mora2000 for this delicious feast. 2011 Bottle, consumed in spring of 2013. Reddish brown pour. Aroma had cherries, wine, barrels, funk, tons of sourness and tartness. Flavor was enamel peeling sourness, tartness that would require some tums, cherries, cinnamon. Incredibly dry and thirst quenching, lively mouthfeel. Excellent, excellent beer!!

bottle from mora2000 at BTBF tasting, rust colored pour with no head, very sour but not offputting , flavors of sour cherries, white grape juice, some lactic qualities, funky basement wine barrel finish

text: Bottle via trade. Pours a brownish-reddish color with a small white head. Aroma is of tart funk, lots of tart and sweet cherries, oak barrel and light vinegar. Taste is complex, sweet cherries, tart cherries, light lactic acid, funk, sourness, some oaky wood, and not much of a sign of the alcohol. Very complex sour, very well done.

Flavor of sour cherry, wet wood, earth, funk, lemons. Good stuff.

Bottle 2011 project. Pour has a deep red amber color and a film of off white head. Aroma has tart cherry, dry acidity, oak, light bourbon, and yeast. Flavor gets a hit of cherry, oak, dry bourbon, tannins, yeast, high acidity, and red grape skins.The base beer is nice and holds up to the treatment with a nice sweet and tart cherry. Some toasted malt hidden amongst the sour flavor.  Sour funk through to the end.  Almost mouth-watering.  A lot going on in this one.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2015 Draft at VSK night at Blint Tiger back on 11/28/2013 with James, Streets, some others. Dark brown pour with no head. Nose is booze, leather and vinegar (theres a first). 10/10 nose. Great acidic and sour palate. Not overdone. Dark fruit, cherry, strawbery, raspberry. Awesome.

Re-rate Aug 2014 (on draft @ Cascade with Erica, Matt):  Deep brown with a red tint and light brown head.  Heavy chocolate-looking lacing.  Muted cherry aroma and then a huge cherry taste.  Not puckery but acidic.

Murky amber pour with a small white head.  Aroma was full of vinegar and sour cherries.  Some caramel and sweet malt.  Flavors were tart as can be with a slight cherry sweetness.  Dry finish with no notes of booze.  Nicely done.  Puckering finish.  Awesome.
Lactic acid, vinegar, tart finish.  Sweet sugar, mixed with sour cherries.  Tastes like its falling off a bit
23rd November 2012THE Fruit Sour tasting. Cheers Bruce! Hazy amber beer, residual pale tan head. Crisp dry palate, light and airy. Vinegar and sharp cherry. Finishes dry. Not bad.
Bottle with Ray and Chris on New Years Day.  Pours a hazy reddish brown with minimal head and lacing.  Nose is tart fruit and soggy oak.  Quite tart, some cherry and oak.

The beer is a touch of a slow gusher, a steady pour into my Bruery tulip produces a two finger thick, pale amber tinged, dark tan colored head. The beer is a concentrated amber color that shows a lightly hazy, bright red hue when held up to the light. The aroma has a fruitiness to it that makes me think of not quite ripe grapes, tannic red wine, and a soft, but somehow bright cherry character towards the finish. Lots of toasted notes are brought out by both some wood character as well as by the caramelized malt notes. There is a spiciness to the nose that is brought out by the wood; it is slightly peppery and sort of leans towards green wood somehow. Notes of vanillin are noticeable at times.

Nicely tart up front, and quite a bit lighter bodied than I was expecting. The sourness lingers through to the finish of each sip where it accentuates a touch of cherry flavors. Lots of woodiness is found in the flavor, spicy, oak-laden, tannic, plus lots of Bourbon flavors in the finish; the latter provide a sort of Bourbon melon character, some definite warming character, and a distinct, somewhat diluted Bourbon flavor that is actually noticeable up front, and then again in the finish of each sip. Soft vanilla notes start to come out as the beer warms up, and the oak softens, and gets less astringent. Soft fruit flavors of cherries, tamarind, hints of melon, some light berry notes, and a definite red wine like fruitiness. The body is light for the strength, but does have some medium feel to this.

Quite nice, more complex due to the multi-barrel aging and the Bourbon barrel character is kept low enough that it adds to the complexity without overwhelming the beer.

Bouteille de 750 ml, avec bouchon de liège, partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal. Arôme: Odeur de cerises sûrettes avec une pointe de bourbon. Apparence: La couleur est brune-ambrée opaque. Saveur: Goût de cerises sûrettes avec une pointe de bourbon et de raisins. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement vineuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût sûrette. (Rating #4428)

Dark amber-brown, moderate sized off-white head, soapy lacing. Shows lots of cherries, lactic tartness, and some acetic notes.  Some wood, bourbon and faint booziness. Medium bodied, appropriate carbonation, fairly acidic, dry finish.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy amber with a small frothy white head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is sour fruit and malt. Medium mouthfeel with a light malt with sour fruit and nice tart finish. Easy to drink, a very good sour ale from Cascade.

750mL bottle, no date, thanks Sebastian! Auburn with a one finger beige, good enough retention. Cherries, lactic and acetic up front, some old wood and bourbon hiding with some caramel behind. Flavor is pretty jammy, def cherry notes with mainly lactic sourness, light acetic acetoney, bourbon lurking in the back. Dry finish, sourness peaked at a 6, some heat noted, but feels like its from the acid and not the alcohol. Low carbonation with a medium body. Quite tasty.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Aroma brilliant with cherries, and incredibly fruity. Appearance is a perfect transluscent brown color with a medium creme-brown head, liquid is hazy. Taste is medium-heavy sour with cherries, heavy heavy cherries. Palate, body is full, texture is thick, carbonation is lively, finish is sour, an explosion in your mouth. Quite possibly one of the finest sours I have drank!

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2012 Bottle... This beer rocks! Hazy brown ale with a small, creamy, off-white head. The aroma is an enjoyable collaboration of cherries, acetic acid, lactic sourness, caramel and roasted barley. There are also undercurrents of whiskey and vanilla here. Medium-bodied with a whole-milk mouthfeel and soft carbonation. The flavor delivers acute, fruity sourness - cherries and blackberries stand out. Finishes tart with a modest measure of caramel. Kudos to ctipping for sharing this world class beer!

Bottle at The Fruit Sour Tasting, London - big thanks to Bruce for the hook-up. Pours muddy, red-brown with a frothy, off-white foam head. Tangy berry aroma, cherries, light booze. Big tart flavor with light sweetness, stones, grape skins. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Moderately dry on the finish with strong tartness, fine woody notes, fruits, heavy acidity. Very good stuff.

On tap at The Stumbling Monk in Seattle, WA. Pours a ruby-amber colored body with a finger-width, frothy, tan head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is ripe cherries with a nice tartness, bourbon, wood, vinous fruits, and a light acidity. Flavor is similar. Lots of tart cherries with a light sweetness, bourbon, wood, vinous fruits, and a light acidity. Hints of vanilla in there as this finishes dry, woody, and tart with a nice fruitiness before leaving a lengthy aftertaste. Medium-light body and a soft, somewhat lively, medium-light carbonation. Overall, a really tasty sour. Dry, tart, and fruity with a bunch of cherries as well as a light, woody bourbon and slight acidity. Very enjoyable.

The beer is ruby to copper colored with a small, quickly vanishing head. The aroma brings sour cherries, bourbon, oak. Smells tart. The flavor carries more oak and is tannic in nature. The bourbon is there, but cherries and a tart sourness are the primary flavors. Acetic finish with some alcohol presence. Similar to Russian River Consecration, a beer of which I am very fond. Very tasty. Overall, I am very glad to have tried this.

Serving type: growler

Reviewed on: 02-11-2012

Bottle.  Light reddish pour.  Aroma is chunky tart and grainy sour with dense berry.  Taste is vinegar-like sour but it works with the tart and berry.  Lingering tartness after each sip.  Fairly clean but slightly corse mouthfeel.  Great, intense sour.

Bottle @ THE fruit sour tasting. Cheers to Bruce! The pours hazy red with a tiny head. The nose is red grapes and strawberry jam sweetness. The taste is more red fruits, mildly vinous and tannic. Oak wood and hints of spice cake. Pissy lemon and acetic funkiness. Big body, a bit boozy. Overall, tasty stuff.

hazy chestnut, wispy cream head, thin ring. Synthetic nose is too sweet, green apple with off playdoh. Spritzy lemon candy, lime at front, mid is clay and paper before acetic rules finish. Thin sticky, oppressive. Yuck.

Bottle at the Tiger.  I ordered some susan but she was kicked so a panicked and ordered this gem and couldnt be more pleased.  pours reddish brown.  nise tart nose of dark fruits.  tastes of great sour cherries, earth, black currants, green grapes, berries, oak, and vinegar in the most pleasant of ways.  Its sharp and clean.  wonderful

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2013 2012 bottle. Ruby red pour with darkish brown hues. Bing cherries dominate the nose; bourbon is in the back seat adding complexity. Smell is seriously awesome. Cherries and oak atop the sour base = deliciousness. Unfortunately, the magic I remember from my first few (fresh) bottles has faded somewhat since the summer release, but this is still an excellent American sour.

Bottle pour at blind tiger with streets and Brendan. Pours a deep hazy red with no head, light lacing. Aroma is sour fruit, sour wood, and nice acidity. Mouthfeel is medium, carbonated and tart with notes of slightly mouth-puckering fruits, sour cherry, light white grapes and oak. Very, very nice.

2011 bottle thanks to Bruce at THE fruit sour tasting. It pours deep ruby, almost purple with a small off-white head. The nose is jam, oak, vanilla, toasted coconut, blackcurrant, red grape and cherry. The taste is fresh dark cherry, blackcurrant yoghurt, jam, lemon, lip-smacking sourness, cherry pip, earth, light vanilla and wood with a tart finish. Medium body, moderate, prickly carbonation and medium-high acidity. Great balance and depth of flavour. Perhaps a touch rougher round the edges and more acidic than Sang Royal but a delicious beer nonetheless.

Bottle courtesy of BrainLair.  Not a very pleasant beer.  Aroma has citrus and tangerine notes but mostly rotten fruit and mold.  Flavor is even worse.  Extremely sour and acetic.  Some tangerine notes.  Really unpleasant.

Bottle, passed around on Black Friday, Scottsdale. Pours a prune cordovan with a soapy, off-white head. Very tart with hints of wood, rose pedals, white wine lees, and pilsener malt.  Cherries by swallow. Not as "yum" as I thought itd be, but still rather delicious.

Bottle - Reddish brown with a thin ring of off-white head. Nose is pear and cherry. Sharp oak too, with a bit of tartness. Taste is really citrusy tart, with oak, vanilla, and a bit of sweet caramel malt. Nice medium body with very soft, fluffy carbonation.

750ml bottle. Rating #132. Interesting beer, something didnt seem right. A few of the guys were saying it smelled like nail polish, which it did just a little bit. One thing for sure was that it was extremely sour, very puckering. Ok beer, just wasnt feeling it. (2562)

text: Bottle. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity sour tart cherry aroma. Fruity sour tart woody cherry flavor. Has a fruity sour tart woody cherry finish.

Pours a dark brown with red hue, decent off- white head which settles. Aroma is tart cherry, lemon, lots of oak, hint of bourbon.  Taste is sour cherry and funk, vinegar with nice oak and vanilla in the finish. Great palate.  One of the best sours Ive had.

Thanks to brewandbbq for hooking me up with this bottle!
Pours a deep garnet brown with a huge tan head that slowly dissipates and leaves much lace on the way down. Smells of balsamic, cherries, lemon and funk. Light alcohol note and a touch of wood. The flavor is complex and varied. Up front I get some sweet cherries and a light sweet maltiness. Tart cherries, a bit of lactic acid and lemons destroy the sweetness in short order. Woody oak come in next with a bit of funk and vinegar and an ever increasing lactic tartness. The finish leaves a lingering sweet tart candy feel on my taste buds. Medium body with a moderate to high level of carbonation and a tart chalky puckering mouthfeel. Very nice Flanders style ale very complex. Maybe I should have asked for more than one bottle!

Pours a rad red .. medium foam .. light lacing .. . mm, this is a nice brew - tart and raspberry/fruit madness .. . very light but solid .. . wish i had gotten more!

2011 Project, bought from the brewery online for $21

It pours a murky rusty colour, started off with over a finger head of foam but that quickly dissipated. Very little lacing left behind.

You can certainly smell the sour cherries and the oak barrel. Some slight note of vanilla there. My nose is happy.

Tart cherries up front in the taste, oak flavours not so much. Alcohol extremely well hidden when it comes to what sits and swirls in my mouth, some definite warming during and after the swallow. Sour, yeah, but not overly so. Very slight hint of a vinegar sourness so I dont *think* that heartburn will be an issue.

Very tasty from the get go; I opened it at near room temp to get all of the flavours rather than opening after pulling from the fridge.

A delightfully delicious Wild Ale that I wish had a bit less alcohol to make it even more drinkable; as is, its still and an easy drop to tip back.

750ml bottle.
Cloudy amber brew, small white head.  Smells incredible - cherry pie, bourbon, oak, and cinnamon.  Easy drinking for the high ABV - great mix of tart and sour.  Delicious!

Bottle shared amongst friends at my "Massive Mikkeller" tasting. Cascade, along with Cantillon, really do have sours down to a science. The balance between the fruit, sourness, tartness and funk is all there. Makes for an incredible drinking experience.

Bottle 750ml. corked @ The Danish Summer Gathering, TFODRBSG12, Ulfborg. Bottle at RBAG, from my commemorative RBAG glass. Pours cloudy deep red/brown, with a thin off-white head, and great lacing. 750 ml bottle shared by lushawn- thanks a ton, LuhShauhun! Pours a hazy brown color with a small beige head that leaves a lasting ring and film. Medium-bodied, with medium carbonation and a sweet, tart mouthfeel. Excellent sour.

Pours brown, opaque in some glasses, translucent warm red notes in others depending on the pour.  Toffee head, moderate to coarse.  Aroma is sharp acetic with bold fruit undertones. Pours dark brown/black. With a light brown head. Aroma is oaky, acidic, fruity especially cherries and berries. Taste follows, bourbon comes in. Very tasty, pretty sour. Great beer

Mahogany with a thick off white head. The nose is a mix of balsamico & rhubarb. Medium bodied with a stinging tartness on the mid palate. The cherry flavors coat the mouth on the back end. The finish is clean & fresh.
Sang Noir. Bottle @ fonefan. Hazy brown body with a medium light brown head. Aroma is light yeast, earthy notes, dust, balsamic, tart. Flavor is tart, balsamic, oak, vinegar. Nice lacings.
Bottle @ Danish Summer Gathering Ulfborg, 2012. Pours ruby amber with a small white head and lacings. Oak, funk , acetone, berries and leather. Quite rough and hot. Ends really dry. Unrefined.

Redish brown, surprisingly dark brown head.  Tart red fruit nose.  Very tart with some oak flavor, crisp carbonation.  Flavor is a bit hollow for lack of a better word, decent beer but not overly impressed.

Aroma is acidic astringent, some Elmers glue, fruit, and oak presence. Sor cherries and other dark fruits lightly tannic. Weird.  Looks murky as shit and is black violet with red edges. No head barely evidence of carb.  Just so sour up front. Hard to read more but I like it. A lot.

This smooth talker has an orange-brown color with an off-white head and an aroma of a standard sour.  Its soft, and not too sour for the style. This is an enjoyable and easy to drink beer very nice!

Bottle @ home. Pours hazy reddish brown with small offwhite head.  Aroma of oak, sweet cherries, light vinegar, almond. Flavor is sweet and sour cherries, oak notes, vinegar. Thin to medium, soft carbonation. 190812

Pouts dark brown not much of a head. Really sour and tart taste cherries and oak. Nice sour beer very enjoyable.

Dark brown color with minimal head.  Aroma of vinegar, dark fruit,and wood.  Sour cherry flavor with some tart funk, and wood.  Really great beer!

Bottle @ FOneFan, Danish Ratebeer Summer Gathering 2012. Unclear dark brown/amber with tiny beige head. Aroma is malt, vinegar, sour and dark fruit. Flavour is malt, vinegar, sour, little dark fruits, sour, wood and a little tart.
Bottle @ Summer Gathering, Ulfborg. Nice head with good duration. Color is hazy brown. Aroma and taste are rich brett, fruits, malt, candy sugar, wood and vinegar. Nice and vinous.

Bottle, 75cl, at TFODRBSG-12. As Sang Noir. An unclear, brown beer topped by a small, dense, light beige head. Some vinegar on the nose, as well as dried fruits and some caramel hints. Well, it might deserve a higher rating, but I think it lacks a bit on complexity. A nice beer though, thats for sure. 120818

Bottle @ TFODRBSG, Ulfborg. Unclear dark reddish brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, vinegar, cherries and light acetone. Flavor is quite sweet, moderate sour and moderate acidic. Dry and moderate acidic finish. 180812
